description: Cap 3-10 cm tall, egg-shaped to conical with honeycomb pattern and primarily vertical ridges. Color gray to whitish to yellowish. Stem hollow, whitish, cap fully attached with no overhang.
habitat: Most common under hardwoods (ash, elm, aspen, sycamore, apple) and occasionally white pine. Prefers damp pockets with non-acidic soil in forests and old orchards.
season: Southern US: March-April, Midwest: April-May, Northeast: May-June. Generally March through June depending on region.
lookalikes: Gyromitra esculenta - DEADLY - brain-like folded cap, associated with conifers
Verpa species - HIGHLY POISONOUS - cap partially attached to stem with cotton-like interior
safety_notes: Must be thoroughly cooked, toxic when raw. Always verify cap fully attached to stem and completely hollow interior by cutting vertically. Cannot be distinguished from similar M. ulmaria without DNA analysis.
